Hello! I am a journalist. A few days ago I was sent to the Crimea, Ukraine to give coverage to celebration of the Day of Ukraine's Fleet. I came to the city of Sevastopol where president of Ukraine also arrived. I must say that I was very much surprised to know that not a single citizen of Sevastopol was allowed to take part in the celebration of NATIONAL holiday! There was only president Yushchenko himself, leaders of nationalistic parties and organizations and the military. Now something about the police. Officers were not simply cordoning off the place of celebration. They outright flooded the city! It appears that they attempted to prevent eventual protest actions or something. To do it, they simply used their billy clubs and kicks in the backside to force everyone keep the house! 
 
 Does this mean that president Yushchenko is only supported by the police, army and avid nationalists? And what about the people? Perhaps, president Yushchenko is simply afraid of meeting his nation because he feels he's going to be egged. Well, looks like he is not going to be re-elected anyway. A totally not popular president! I don't think that European state leaders should anchor any hopes with him.

Ukrainian election's finally over! 
 Honestly, I'm fed up with the Election in Ukraine serial! Now done with it! They have expressed their will, votes are counted, and he who got more votes becomes president. So much for it! Granted that international observers said 'there was no major evidence of fraud' (see this for instance guardian. co. uk/world/2010/feb/07/ukraine-election-viktor-yanukovych Exit polls suggest Viktor Yanukovych heading for victory in Ukraine presidential election | World news | The Guardian) then it's clear. I expect now that Tymoshenko would once again like five years ago make mess of the election, gather people on Maidan Nezalezhnosti, file appeals, etc. No! That will do it! The election was transparent and democratic, without any fraud. Now let them move on with new president!
Yuricon

Hello! I am a Ukrainian and here's what I can tell you about current situation in my country. 
 Even though the election is over now and thanks God neither Yulia Tymoshenko nor Viktor Yushchenko were able to win presidency, the situation here remains very complicated. These two were apparently leading the country for raise of nationalism and even now as they both are in opposition they try to do just everything they can to prevent the new presidential cabinet from taking the country out of crisis. The crisis does not only mean problems in economy but also that the "orange team" had deliberately led the country away from the right direction. Raise of nationalistic moods, heroization of such ambiguous personalities like Roman Shukhevich and Stepan Bandera who were recognized to be sidekicks of Nazi Germany long ago - this is what the "orange team" was after when they were in power. 
 But now we have a new leader who tries to make real steps for taking the country out of crisis. He has assigned Dmitri Tabachnik minister of education for his serious intentions to uproot nationalism as such in Ukraine. And it was just the next day after his assignment that our opposition demanded his immediate resignation! You see? They just block all positive reforms! At this rate we will never get out of crisis thanks to the "orange" politicians and, moreover, will never become the civilized country!
JPSartre12

Sibilla

We all know that the lection was a success this time as Ukrainians finally managed to get rid of the "orange team", namely Yushchenko and Tymoshenko. Well done, because these two almost brought the country to collapse. After this things got to go much better in Ukraine, don't they? But no, the trouble is that now Yushchenko and Tymoshenko stayed in opposition where they stonewall the normal process of recovery of the state. Besides, they fight against each other with the gloves off for the post of the leader of opposition, which is also no good. Granted that when they were president and prime-minister they didn't show good results, it becomes clear that as leaders of opposition they won't be able to work effectively either. You see, Ukraine need to have new politicians in the opposition, some new leaders, some fresh blood if you know what I mean. Only then that country may expect any quick recovery. 
 
 And there is another reason why neither Tymoshenko nor Yushchenko should be oppositional leaders - that's the shortest way for presidency. I reckon that the previous five years of "orange regime" were quite enough for Ukraine to learn who's who, don't you think so?
